thesis.description: The first determinations of the electrical conductivity of dibasic organic acids were made by Ostwald in 1888, who examined among others a few of the simpler alky I substituted malonic acids vyith the purpose of testing his dilution law for binary electriytes it having previously been found that weak dibasic organic acids dissociate into two ions and not into three: [...]
thesis.creator: Meldrum, William B.

thesis.description: Throughout the Elizabethan period, literature was the honoured occupation of the worthiest minds. Scarce any man thought of himself so seriously or of life so holily, as to sniff at the writer's art. Poetry was felt to be true. Great poets spoke out in the Drama with a frank strength, - mirrored forth human nature with reality and ideality. "Look in thine heart and write", the keynote of those sonnets in which Sir Philip Sidney gives expression to his ideal passion, might have been Marlowe's motto, or S&akspere1s, or Ben Jonson's. Despite isolated detractors like Gossen, poetry was never in danger of being discountenanced by the intelligent Elizabethan ; it could claim the attention of all sane and able men, and the devotion of the highest genius. [...]
thesis.creator: McNeill, John T.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Partisan poetry of Roundhead and Cavalier.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Of all the elements discovered undoubtedly - in proportion to its occurence on the earth - the least is known about the element beryllium. It has been estimated that from one tenth to one hundredth of one per cent. of the earth's crust is beryllium, comparing this with F.W. Clarke's estimate (1908) of the percentage composition by weight of the earth's crust [...] we see that beryllium is relatively an exceedingly common element, it being somewhere between sulphur and bromine, and yet to the average person it is so little known as to be almost unheard of. [...]
thesis.creator: Greaves, Clifford.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Beryllium.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Bitterly opposed to the measures of burgh reform much discussed at the time, and fondly clinging to "ancient opinions", Sir Walter Scott wrote to Croker in the year 1826:- "Scotland, completely liberalised as she is in a fair way of being, will be the most dangerous neighbour to England that she has had since 1639... If you UNSCOTCH us you will find us damned mischievous Englishmen. The restless and yet laborious and constantly watchful character of the people, their desire for speculation in politics or anything else, only restrained by some proud feelings about their own country, now become antiquated, and which bold measures will tend much to destroy, will make them under a wrong direction, the most formidable revolutionists who ever took the field of innovation." Scott is obviously prejudiced by national and party feeling, combined with his natural conservatism. His words not only indicate the confusion between the terms liberalism and revolution, common in the minds of those who feared Jacobinism, but also suggest an interesting relationship between England and Scotland. [...]
thesis.creator: Harbert, Eleanor.
thesis.subject: Hiostory.
thesis.title: Scottish sources of British liberalism.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: To establish a Canadian steel industry, capable of supplying the entire domestic consumption, requires a very careful survey of the national resources and the best and most economical utilization of domestic raw materials. A great steel industry in this important part of the British Empire should depend for its basic requirements on Canadian iron-ore, fuel and hydro-electric energy. [...]

thesis.title: The reduction of iron ores by solid and gaseous reducing reagents at temperatures below that of fusion.

thesis.description: Of the many interesting properties of hydrogen peroxide, that which led most directly to the undertaking of this investigation, was the discovery of the fact that when dry hydrogen chloride gas is passed into anhydrous hydrogen peroxide chlorine is liberated, even at low temperatures. [...] The first experiments revealed the remarkable fact that even low concentrations of hydrochloric acid would bring about the decomposition of fairly dilute solutions of hydrogen peroxide, without however liberating chlorine. [...]

thesis.title: Properties of pure hydrogen peroxide.

thesis.description: The theories about the origin of the belief in fairies are so confused and intermingled that is is impossible to divide one sharply from another. Traces of three different lines of idea may, however, be detached. The first theory states that, when the paleolithic men were driven from their homes by races more advanced in civilized arts, they took refuge among the rocks and caves of the wilder parts of the country. Here, of necessity, they were forced to penetrate into the secrets of Nature; they located the minerals, acquired an uncanny power of foretelling the weather, learned to move with astonishing swiftness, to conceal themselves in holes invisible to their conquerors, and so on. [...]
thesis.creator: McDonald, Jessie.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: The fairy element in English poetry.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The word "purification" in the gas industry is understood to mean the removal of certain gaseous and colloidal constituents from the main bulk of the hydrocarbons. thesis.description: As ons of the great world-hooks, the Republic of Plato has throughout many ages of different activities, and interests, among scholars of widely diverse casts of mind, at all times claimed careful perusal and profound study. It represents the full bloom of the Greek genius for philosophy. To the Greeks, the possibility of a mortal acquiring a connected view of things which might explain all existence, presented a problem of intense interest, and it must be admitted that, as a people, they did more to advance toward such a view than: the members of any other single race. And in the theories of Plato we find the highest point to which Greek philosophy; attained. Leaving entirely the world of sense, he constructs a great overfloating Kingdom of Ideas of which ordinary so- called "objects" are really but images or adumbrations. [...]
thesis.creator: Maclean, Herbert B.
thesis.subject: Philosophy.
thesis.title: Plato's Republic from the standpoint of philosophy and education.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

The following is a skeleton outline of the process : [...]

thesis.description: Texada Island is composed chiefly of igneous rocks comprising extrusive, intermediate and intrusive varieties. The volcanic rocks, including the hypabyssal type, are the most widespread, while plutonic and dike rocks are well represented. It is proposed in this paper to refer briefly to the geography, topography, and general geology of the island, andthen to describe the various types of igneous rocks, including some pyroclastic rocks which are intimately associated. [...]
thesis.creator: Hayes, Albert O.
thesis.subject: Petrography.
thesis.title: The petrography of some of the igneous rocks of Texada Island.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In the applications of the elliptic functions and their methods to Geometry, Algebra, and Physics, it is seen that the different problems call for different standard forms of these functions. In a treatment of the properties of the cubic curve, for example, the variables employed are generally the p-function and its argument, so extensively developed by the researches of Weierstrass ; whereas in such problems as, say, the discussion of the form of the surfaces of lightwaves in crystals, the functions sn, en, and dn of Jacobi enter most readily into the analysis. [...]
thesis.creator: Hatcher, Albert G.
thesis.subject: Mathematics.
thesis.title: Numerical evaluation of elliptic functions.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A relation has been shown to exist between the concentration of calcium chloride present and the temperature at which the contraction of white connective tissue fibres takes place. thesis.creator: Tidmarsh, Clarence J.
thesis.subject: Physiology.
thesis.title: Experiments on the contraction of white connective tissue fibres.

thesis.description: In the development of the International Socialist movement, there has gradually become apparent a somewhat curious paradox. There is, at the present time, no mode of speech more common than that which characterizes America as the new and Europe as the old world, which speaks of daughter nations and mother lands, which contrasts the young progressive, vigorous peoples of the West with the old, conservative, decadent races from whence they sprang. [...]
thesis.creator: Troop, George R.
thesis.subject: Economics.
Socialism -- Canada.
thesis.title: Socialism in Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The word Absorption should be used as the name for the general phenomenon which includes any case of the retention of a liquid within a solid, or of a gas or vapour within a solid or liquid, when there is no apparent evidence of chemical activity. The absorption of gas by a liquid is what is ordinarily known as the solution of the gas by the liquid. The absorption of gas by a solid, sometimes called "occlusion," includes (1) the mechanical retention and adhesion of the gas or vapour in the crevices between particles of the solid, and (2) in the capillary spaces of individual particles, and also (3) the "'adsorption," or condensation upon the surface of the solid, of the gaseous molecules, this condensation being due to molecular attraction between the gas and solid. [...]
thesis.creator: Boyle, R. W.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Absorption and adsorption with reference to the radioactive emanations.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
